    hotstepper.Step module¶

    class hotstepper.Step.Step(start=None, end=None, weight=None, use_datetime=False, basis=None)¶

    Bases: hotstepper.Steps.Steps

    This is a wrapper class to make life seem alittle easier if only a single step function is needed and using the plural Steps seems odd.

    Parameters
    startint, float, datetime_like, Optional

    A quick convenience parameter if this Steps object consists of 1 or 2 steps, the start key can be passed directly in the constructor.

    endint, float, datetime_like, Optional

    A quick convenience parameter if this Steps object consists of 1 or 2 steps, the end key can be passed directly in the constructor.

    weightint, float, Optional

    A quick convenience parameter if this Steps object consists of 1 or 2 steps, the weight is the step value.

    basisBasis, Optional

    The is the basis function that will be used for all steps associated with this step function. The default basis -> Basis() is the Heaviside function

    \[heta(t) = \left\{ egin{array}{ll} 0 & \quad t < 0 1 & \quad t \geq 0 \end{array}\]
    ight.

    where $t in mathbb{R}

    Methods

    __call__(x)

    Call self as a function.

    add(steps)

    Add an array of step or steps objects to this collection of steps.

    add_direct([pd_data_start, pd_data_end, …])

    Add an array of individual step objects to this collection of steps.

    add_steps(step_data_np)

    Add an array of internal step data as per the DataModel used internally by HotStepper.

    apply_math_function(caller, other, math_function)

    Apply the supplied function to two objects evaluated at the union of all their unique step keys.

    apply_reduction_function(steps_to_combine, …)

    Apply the supplied function to all provided objects evaluated at the union of all their unique step keys.

    clamp([lbound, ubound])

    Clamp the steps between lower and upper limits, this function is equivalent to zeroing out the steps beyond the lower and upper limits.

    clear()

    Clear all the step data defined within the steps object, the same as defining a new Steps object with no data, except will retain the assigned datetime flag and base.

    clip([lbound, ubound])

    Clip the steps between lower and upper limits, this function is equivalent to taking a slice of the steps and returning a new steps object only containing data between the clip boundries.

    describe([precision, return_dataframe])

    Generate a table containing a number of standard statistical metrics for the steps data.

    ecdf_plot([ax])

    Plot an empirical cummulative distribution function of the cummulative step values.

    filter_values(other, operation_func[, …])

    This function is used to create a filtered version of the steps by removing steps not evaluating to true from applying the comparison function at all step change locations.

    histogram([bins, axis, ts_grain])

    Calculates a histogram for the corresponding step function values

    histogram_plot([bins, axis, precision, …])

    Plot a histogram of the cummulative step values.

    plot_rolling_step([rolling_function, …])

    Plot the result of applying a reduction function to a rolling window across the step values.

    read_array([start, end, weight, …])

    Read arrays of values for start, end and weight values that represent either the cummulative value of the data steps or the direct step values seperately, indexed by the start and possibly end arrays.

    read_dataframe(data[, start, end, weight, …])

    Read a Pandas dataframe with values that represent either the cummulative value of the data steps or the direct step values seperately.

    step(x[, process_input])

    This is a mathematical function definition of the Steps object, this is a dynamically created formula representation that can be passed an array of values to evaluate the steps function at.

    step_changes()

    ”

    summary([plot_params])

    Plot and display summary details and statistics for the Steps object.

    hotstepper.Steps module¶

    class hotstepper.Steps.Steps(use_datetime=False, start=None, end=None, weight=None, basis=None)¶

    Bases: hotstepper.mixins.StepsPlottingMixin.StepsPlottingMixin, hotstepper.mixins.FilterFunctionsMixin.FilterFunctionsMixin, hotstepper.mixins.MathFunctionsMixin.MathFunctionsMixin, hotstepper.core.AbstractSteps.AbstractSteps

    Class representing a complex step function made of individual step objects. The Steps object can be treated as a mathemtical function in Numpy and as a Python object.

    Methods

    __call__(x)

    Call self as a function.

    add(steps)

    Add an array of step or steps objects to this collection of steps.

    add_direct([pd_data_start, pd_data_end, …])

    Add an array of individual step objects to this collection of steps.

    add_steps(step_data_np)

    Add an array of internal step data as per the DataModel used internally by HotStepper.

    apply_math_function(caller, other, math_function)

    Apply the supplied function to two objects evaluated at the union of all their unique step keys.

    apply_reduction_function(steps_to_combine, …)

    Apply the supplied function to all provided objects evaluated at the union of all their unique step keys.

    clamp([lbound, ubound])

    Clamp the steps between lower and upper limits, this function is equivalent to zeroing out the steps beyond the lower and upper limits.

    clear()

    Clear all the step data defined within the steps object, the same as defining a new Steps object with no data, except will retain the assigned datetime flag and base.

    clip([lbound, ubound])

    Clip the steps between lower and upper limits, this function is equivalent to taking a slice of the steps and returning a new steps object only containing data between the clip boundries.

    Generate a table containing a number of standard statistical metrics for the steps data.

    Plot an empirical cummulative distribution function of the cummulative step values.

    histogram([bins, axis, ts_grain])

    Plot a histogram of the cummulative step values.

    plot_rolling_step([rolling_function, …])

    Plot the result of applying a reduction function to a rolling window across the step values.

    read_array([start, end, weight, …])

    Read arrays of values for start, end and weight values that represent either the cummulative value of the data steps or the direct step values seperately, indexed by the start and possibly end arrays.

    read_dataframe(data[, start, end, weight, …])

    Read a Pandas dataframe with values that represent either the cummulative value of the data steps or the direct step values seperately.

    This is a mathematical function definition of the Steps object, this is a dynamically created formula representation that can be passed an array of values to evaluate the steps function at.

    add(steps)¶

    Add an array of step or steps objects to this collection of steps.

    Parameters

    steps (array_like) – An array of step or steps object.

    Returns

    A new steps object containing all the step data from all provided step objects.

    Return type

    Steps

    add_direct(pd_data_start=None, pd_data_end=None, pd_data_weight=None)¶

    Add an array of individual step objects to this collection of steps.

    Parameters

    • pd_data_start (array_like, Optional) – Array of values that represent the step start key locations.

    • pd_data_end (array_like, Optional) – Array of values that represent the step end key locations.

    • pd_data_weight (array_like, Optional) – Array of values that represent the step values.

    • note:: (.) – If more than one array of values are assigned, all arrays must be the same length.

    Returns

    Return type

    Steps

    add_steps(step_data_np)¶

    Add an array of internal step data as per the DataModel used internally by HotStepper.

    Parameters

    step_data_np (array_like.) – Array of step arrays to be directly added to the current steps object.

    Returns

    Return type

    Steps

    clamp(lbound=None, ubound=None)¶

    Clamp the steps between lower and upper limits, this function is equivalent to zeroing out the steps beyond the lower and upper limits. The returned steps will contain the specified lower and upper limit keys inclusively.

    <<<<<<< HEAD:docs/_build/html/_modules/hotstepper.html

    Note

    This function will not preserve the step values at the clamp boundries, if you wish to preserve the values beyond the boundries, please use the clip function.

    =======

    NOTE: This function will not preserve the step values at the clamp boundries, if you wish to preserve the values beyond the boundries, please use the clip function.

    >>>>>>> f3e81cf1a36eafdefa0d0fed9259d5a332d9794e:docs/_build/html/modules/hotstepper.html
    clip(lbound=None, ubound=None)¶

    Clip the steps between lower and upper limits, this function is equivalent to taking a slice of the steps and returning a new steps object only containing data between the clip boundries. The boundry values provided may or may not be returned, as the closest step key value within the specificied range will form the new boundry.

    <<<<<<< HEAD:docs/_build/html/_modules/hotstepper.html

    Note

    This function will preserve the step values at the clip boundries, if you wish to zero out values beyond the boundries, please use the clamp function.

    =======

    NOTE: This function will preserve the step values at the clip boundries, if you wish to zero out values beyond the boundries, please use the clamp function.

    lboundint, float, datetime_like, Optional

    The lower step key boundry (x axis value) of the returned steps object, the exact start key of the return object will be the key value >= lbound.

    uboundint, float, datetime_like, Optional

    The upper step key boundry (x axis value) of the returned steps object, the exact start key of the return object will be the key value <= ubound.

    Returns

    A new steps object that has been clipped at the provided boundries.

    Return type

    Steps

    See also

    clamp()
